column2: name           = The House by the Cemetery
image          = The House by the Cemetery poster.jpg
story          = Elisa Livia Briganti<ref name=\"archiv-ita\">{{cite web

Quella villa accanto al cimitero}}) is a 1981 Italian [[horror film]] directed by [[Lucio Fulci]]. The film stars [[Catriona MacColl]], [[Paolo Malco]], [[Ania Pieroni]], [[Giovanni Frezza]], Silvia Collatina and [[Dagmar Lassander]]. Its plot revolves around a series of murders taking place in a New England home–a home which happens to be hiding a gruesome secret within its basement walls.

column1: A woman (Daniela Doria) is in an abandoned house looking for her boyfriend. After she discovers his body stabbed with scissors, she is stabbed in the head with a French knife, and her body is dragged through a cellar door.

In [[New York City]], Bob (Giovanni Frezza) and his parents, Norman and Lucy Boyle (Paolo Malco and Catriona MacColl), are moving into the same house. Norman's ex-colleague, Dr. Peterson, who murdered his mistress before committing suicide, was the previous owner. The Boyles are to stay there, whilst Norman researches old houses. As his mother packs, Bob looks at a photograph of a house and notices a girl in it. In New Whitby, [[Boston]], Bob waits in his parents' car while they collect the house keys. The girl from the photograph appears across the street. The girl, Mae (Silvia Collatina), whom only Bob can see, warns him to stay away. In the real estate office, Mrs. Gittleson (Dagmar Lassander) is annoyed when her colleague hands the couple \"the Freudstein keys\". She insists it is called \"Oak Mansion\", and promises to find the Boyles a babysitter.

Oak Mansion is in a poor state of repair. The cellar door is locked and nailed shut. A woman arrives and introduces herself as Ann, the babysitter (Ania Pieroni). That night, Norman hears noises and finds Ann unblocking the cellar door. The next day, Norman goes to the library to peruse Peterson's materials. The chief librarian, Mr. Wheatley (Carlo De Mejo), appears to recognize him. but Norman claims he is mistaken. The assistant librarian, Daniel Douglas (Giampaolo Saccarola), then informs Norman that Peterson conducted private research at the house. He studied records of area disappearances and other demographic data.

Mae shows Bob a tombstone on the grounds marked \"Mary Freudstein\" and says she is not really buried there. Indoors, Lucy finds the tombstone of \"Jacob Tess Freudstein\" while sweeping the hallway. When Norman returns, he reassures her that some older houses have indoor tombs because of the hard wintry ground. Norman opens the cellar door and walks down the stairs, only to be attacked by a bat, which won't let go until he stabs it repeatedly. Spooked, the family drives down to the real estate office and demands to be re-housed, but are told it will be a few more days before they can move. While the Boyles are at hospital to treat Norman's injuries from the bat, Mrs. Gittleson arrives at the house to tell them of a new property. Letting herself in, she stands over the Freudstein tombstone, which cracks apart, pinning her ankle. A figure emerges, stabs her in the neck with a fireplace poker, and drags her into the cellar.

The next morning, Lucy finds Ann cleaning a bloodstain on the kitchen floor. Ann eludes Lucy's questions about the stain. Over coffee, Norman tells Lucy that he's discovered that Freudstein was a [[Victorian era
column2: Victorian]] surgeon who conducted illegal experiments. Norman must travel to New York to research Freudstein. On the way, Norman visits the library and finds an audio cassette of Peterson's, which documents Peterson's increasing madness and reveals what he discovered about Freudstein. Norman destroys the cassette by dropping it into a furnace pipe.

column1: At the house, Ann goes to the cellar looking for Bob and hears childlike sobbing sounds. Freudstein decapitates her after slashing her throat. Bob sees Ann's head, and exits screaming. Lucy returns to find Bob crying in his room, but refuses to believe Bob's account about Ann. That evening, Bob returns to the cellar looking for Ann but gets locked in. Lucy hears Bob's cries and tries to open the cellar door. When she cannot open it, Norman returns and hacks the door with a hatchet. The rotting right hand of Freudstein (Giovanni De Nava) appears and restrains Bob against the door as the hatchet chops through it. One of Norman's axe blows through the door severs the ghoul's seemingly normal left hand, and he staggers back down the stairs.

Norman and Lucy finally get into the cellar, which contains several mutilated bodies (including Ann, Mrs. Gittleson, and the couple from the beginning of the film), surgical equipment, and a [[slab (casting)
column2: slab]]. Freudstein is a living corpse with rotting flesh. Norman tells Lucy that the 150-year-old Freudstein lives by using his victims' parts to regenerate blood cells. Norman attacks Freudstein, but the ghoul twists the hatchet away. Grabbing a knife from the slab Norman stabs Freudstein, causing rotten flesh and maggots to ooze out of his old lab coat. Freudstein grabs Norman and rips open his throat. Lucy and Bob climb a ladder leading to the underside of the cracked tombstone. Lucy strains to shift the stone, but Freudstein grabs her and drags her down the stairs, killing her by ramming her head into the concrete floor. As Freudstein advances up the ladder, Bob strains to escape. As Freudstein grabs Bob's leg, he is suddenly pulled upwards by Mae. With Mae is her mother, Mary Freudstein (Teresa Rossi Passante), who tells them it's time to leave. Mrs. Freudstein leads Mae and Bob down the wintry grove into an apparent ghost world.

column1: *[[Catriona MacColl]] as Lucy Boyle (credited as Katherine MacColl)
*Daniela Doria as the first female victim
*Kenneth A. Olsen as Harold (credited as John Olson)
Fulci later claimed that after making ''[[The Black Cat (1981 film)
column3: The Beyond]]'' that he wanted to make a film in tribute to [[HP Lovecraft]] without the film being based on one of his stories.{{sfn
column9: p=86}} Screenwriter [[Dardano Sacchetti]] was inspired by [[Henry James]]' ''[[The Turn of the Screw]]''.{{sfn
column12: p=86}} Sacchetti also stated the film was based on his own personal experiences as a child, being born in a large country house with a large dark basement and that age 9 he had to cross a cemetery at night.{{sfn
column15: p=86}} In his biography, Fulci spoke negatively about Sacchetti's contributions as a screenwriter saying that ''The House by the Cemetery'' was derivative of scenes from ''[[The House That Screamed (1969 film)
column19: p=86}} The film went through several changes from the original story by [[Elisa Briganti]] and the script by Sacchetti.{{sfn
column22: p=89}}  The script was originally titled ''La notte dell'inferno'' ({{translation
column23: The Night of Hell}}) which became ''La casa di Freudstein'' and then ''Quella casa accanto al cimitero''.{{sfn
column26: p=89}} Sacchetti's script was revised by Fulci and [[Giorgio Mariuzzo]], Mariuzzo claimed he worked as a [[script doctor]] slightly changing work stating that Sacchetti's scripts were often too short.{{sfn
column29: p=89}} Sacchetti commented on this stating that \"Mariuzzo always intervened afterwards, either because I had to leave to work on another film or refused to make those changes that Lucio demanded. That was the reason for our arguments.\"{{sfn

column1: ''The House by the Cemetery'' was shot on location in [[New York City
column5: p=85}} The film was also shot in studios at De Paolis In.Co.R. Studios in Rome.{{sfn
column8: p=85}} Shooting the film took eight weeks between March 16 and May 1981.{{sfn
column11: p=85}} The film was made on a budget of approximately 600 million [[Italian lire]].{{sfn
column14: p=85}} Despite the credits stating that the special make-up effects were provided by [[Giannetto di Rossi]] and [[Maurizio Trani]], only Trani worked on the film.{{sfn

column1: The Italian ratings board asked for a brief six-second cut in ''The House by the Cemetery'' where [[Dagmar Lassander]]'s character Laura Gittleson is murdered.{{sfn
column4: p=91}} The film opened in [[Turin]] on August 14, 1981.{{sfn
column7: p=84}} and was distributed by Medusa Distribuzione.{{sfn
column23: df=dmy-all}}</ref> The film grossed a total of 1,407,981,297 lire in Italy, making it Fulci's most financially successful horror film of the 1980s.{{sfn
column29: p=91}} Prior to the films theatrical release in France, it was shown at the ''Festival International  du film fantastique et de science-fiction'' in Paris with Fulci's earlier film ''[[The Black Cat (1981 film)
column33: p=92}} It was released in France on March 24, 1982.{{sfn

column1: The film was released in the United Kingdom on October 15, 1982 where it was distributed by Eagle Films.{{sfn
column7: p=92}} The film was passed with cuts by the [[BBFC]] involving scenes being trimmed involving Ann and Laura's murders which gave the film a 84 minute and 49 second running time.{{sfn
column10: p=92}} This version of the film was released on home video in the UK and was later placed on the [[video nasties]] list after the [[Video Recordings Act 1984]].{{sfn
column13: p=92}} It was re-released on home video in 1988 with four minutes and eleven seconds of the film cut.{{sfn
column16: p=92}} The film was re-released on May 29, 2001<ref>{{cite web
column21: title=DVD NEWS BRIEFS: Anchor Bay in May; Aguilera on DVD; Koch’s VaultKoch’s Vault
column25: accessdate=September 6, 2019}}</ref> with only 33 seconds cut and again in 2009 uncut.{{sfn

column1: It was re-released by [[Blue Underground]] on [[Blu-ray]] and DVD on 25 October 2011 with a new 2K transfer.

column3: title='The House by the Cemetery' Announced for Blu-ray

column1: From contemporary reviews, Julian Petley (''[[Monthly Film Bulletin]]'') commented that the film had a \"Frankenstein theme\" but that \"the film adds little to the well-worked legend\" and that \"this would matter less were the film visually richer, but for the most part it is comparatively sober and restrained, at least by Fulci standards\"<ref name=\"mfb\">{{cite magazine
column2: title=Quella villa accanto al cimitero (The House by the Cemetery)
column9: page=20}}</ref> Petley continued that \"the film undeniably has its moments–Bob's escape from the cellar; the human debris of Freudstein's laboratory; an attack by a particularly ferocious and tenacious bat; the climactic appearance of the horribly mutated Freudstein\"<ref name=\"mfb\" /> Giovanna Grassi of ''[[Corriere della Sera]]'' dismissed it as an \"Italian ''[[The Shining (film)
column10: Shining]]''\" and concluded it to be \"a condensation of rip-offs,commonplaces and badly repeated horror conventions.\"{{sfn
column22: language=Italian}}</ref> Aldo Vigano of ''[[La Stampa]]'' commented on the use of children in the film, stating that \"to see children involved in such a gruesome and oppressive horror story will perhaps cause disconcert and discomfort, rather than pity in many spectators.\"{{sfn
column29: title=Nella horror story anche i bambini
column31: language=Italian}}</ref> In France, Philippe Ross of  ''La Revue du cinéma'' proclaimed that Fulci had to show \"us something other than these endless scenes of butchery who truly become more and more painful and soporific\"{{sfn
column42: page=53}}</ref> [[Christophe Gans]] reviewed the film in ''{{ill
column45: }}'' stated that \"Except for two or three welcome details [...] the suspense \"for laughter\", so appreciated by American filmmakers, here becomes particularly tedious\"{{sfn
column57: authorlink=Christophe Gans}}</ref> Gans praised the films visuals, noting \"melancholic, wintery photography\" while still concluding that the film's \"repertoire of gimmicks repeated or borrowed from Argento, our greatest regrets is the absence of madness in the explanation of the monster, yelled amid the din of a stretched suspense.\"{{sfn

column1: From retrospective reviews, film review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reported an approval rating of 38%, based on {{nowrap
column2: 8 reviews}}, with a [[rating average]] of 4.7/10.<ref name=\"rottomatoes\">{{cite web
column3: title=The House By The Cemetery (Quella villa accanto al cimitero) (1981) - Rotten Tomatoes
column8: Time Out]]'' called the film \"a hack-work of almost awesome incoherence\".<ref>{{cite book
column15: page=304}}</ref> [[Allmovie]] praised the film, complimenting its atmosphere.<ref>{{cite web

column1: →‎Sony PlayStation,safe,DJ Kaito,"'''''Phoenix Games''''' is a partly-defunct Dutch video game publisher founded by Willie Horden, Paul Share and Steve Share, that released a large amount of low-effort titles for the Sony [[PlayStation]], [[PlayStation 2]], [[Nintendo DS]], [[Microsoft Windows]] and the Nintendo [[Wii]]. They had contracts with over 50 developer Studios around the globe.

They published games based on [[Dingo Pictures]] films on the aforementioned consoles (barring Windows). Their last known published game was Lion and the King 3 on Nintendo DS, released on February 12th, 2010.

The German Video Game Archive claims that they published 99 games on the PlayStation 2 alone.<ref name=\":0\">[http://www.gamereset.de/va/coverstrophen.html Coverstropfen] on German Videogamearchive</ref>

Phoenix Games was devised between three companies, Phoenix Games B.V., Phoenix Games Ltd. and Phoenix Games Asia. The group was an exhibitor at E3 in 2005.<ref>[https://www.giantbomb.com/e3-2005/3015-3437/ E3 2005] Giantbomb.com</ref> Also they went to ECTS2003.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Phoenix Games: PS2, PSX, PC and XBOX

column1: Founded in May 2002 by Willie Horden<ref>[https://www.linkedin.com/in/williehorden/?originalSubdomain=nl Willie Horden] LinkedIn Profile - Only Visible for Logged in Users</ref> and Paul and Steve Share. They had a UK subsidiary based in Leicester. They were exhibitors of E3 2004<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Getting an education in video games at E3
column7: access-date=2020-04-12}}</ref> 2005<ref>[https://www.giantbomb.com/e3-2006/3015-3439/ List of Exhibitos at E3 2006] on Giantbomb.com</ref> and 2006<ref>{{Cite web
column12: access-date=2020-04-12}}</ref> and were located in De Pinckart 46g, 5674 CC Nuenen in the Netherlands.

column1: Phoenix Games B.V. declared bankruptcy on August 3rd, 2010. On March 27th, 2012 the bankruptcy was suspended due to a lack of income.<ref>[https://drimble.nl/faillissementen/noord-brabant/eindhoven/17160750/phoenix-games-holland-bv.html Phoenix Games] on drimble.nl (Dutch)</ref>

Phoenix Games LTD is still an active registered company in the UK located at 48 Boundary Rd, Newark, Notts, United Kingdom, NG24 4AL.<ref>[https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/08493645/officers Phoenix Games LTD.] at UK Goverment Companies House</ref> Their original address was 53 Malcolm Way, Snaresbrook, London, E11 1PW.
Phoenix Games Asia was located at 24 Sukhumvit, Soi 11, Unit 3B, Sukhumvit Road Bangkok 10110, Thailand, Klongtoey Nua, Wattana. It is unknown if this company still exists or if it was closed down.
The company's titles took only around 3-5 months to develop. At some point, they planned releasing their games to the PSP<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=75 reasons to buy PlayStation Portable
column13: access-date=2020-04-12}}</ref> and Xbox. The original store prices of the games were between 6.99 - 12.99 GBP. The mauals ans games are availeble in English, French, German, Italian, Portuguese and Spanish.

column1: In early 2010 Phoenix Games re-released some of their Games rebranded as \"Simulations\" to German PC audiences.
Do to the populatity of their games on the Internet and the sometimes small prints, some games are selling for a good amount of money.
All 99 PS2 covers were featured on the 2013 Gamescom art gallery \"Coverstrophen\".<ref name=\":0\" />
In 2015 the [[Angry Video Game Nerd]] covered \"Snow White and the 7 Clever Boys in his \"Bad Game Cover Art\" Series.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UdfFiUM10FU</ref>
Paul Share also founded [[Midas Interactive]] in 1998.

The PS2 boxart for Peter Pan stole official Kingdom Hearts artwork, more specifically, artwork depicting Destiny Islands, a world in the series.<ref>[https://www.reddit.com/r/KingdomHearts/comments/438v59/you_guys_know_those_terrible_phoenix_games_with/ Reddit Post]  by u/TheGamedawg</ref>

Both before and after the group existed, there were companies that were formed with the same name. From 1978 to 1981, an American company named [[Phoenix Games]] produced games, best known for the game [[Bushido (role-playing game)
column2: Bushido]]. In 2019, Klaas Kersing founded a gaming company in Germany with the same name.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: * Willie (Will) Horden (sales director until February 2005/managing director until June 2009)
* Ilse van de Vossenberg Vogels (production administrator)
*''...noch mehr Dalmatiner:'' released as ''Dalmatians 2,'' ''Dalmatians 3'' & ''Dalmatians 4'' (for the PS, PS2 and the Wii/DS, respectively)
* ''Das unglaubliche Fussballspiel der Tiere:'' released as ''Animal Football'' & ''Animal Soccer World'' (for the PS and PS2, respectively)
*''Atlantis: Der verlorene Kontinent:'' released as ''Atlantis: The Lost Continent ''& ''Empire of Atlantis ''(for the PS and PS2, respectively)
*''Toys: Das Geburtstagsgeschenk:'' released as ''Toys ''&'' The Toys Room ''(for the PS and PS2, respectively)
*''Abenteuer im Land der Dinosaurier:'' released as ''Dinosaurs ''&'' Dinosaur Adventure ''(for the PS and PS2, respectively)
*''Ein Fall für die Mäusepolizei:'' released as ''Detective Mouse'' & ''The Mouse Police ''(for the PS and PS2, respectively)
*''Winkie der kleine Bär:'' released as ''Winky the Little Bear'' & ''Countryside Bears'' (for the PS and PS2, respectively)
* Der König der Tiere: das grosse Abenteuer: released as ''Lion and the King 2, Son of the Lion King'' & ''Lion and the King 3 ''(for the PS, PS2 and the Wii/DS, respectively)
* Peter Pan (Longsoft Multimedia): released as ''Peter Pan'' & ''Peter Pan's Playground'' (PS2, Wii, DS)
* Snow White and the Magnificent Seven (Longsoft Multimedia): released as Snow White and the 7 Clever Boys &Princess Snow White (PS2)
* Cinderella (Longsoft Multimedia): released as ''Cinderella'' & ''Cinderella's Fairytale'' (Wii, PS2)
* Pinocchio (Longsoft Multimedia): released as ''Adventures of Pinocchio'' (Wii, PS2, DS)
* Hansel & Gretel (Longsoft Multimedia): released as ''Hansel & Gretel ''(PS2)
* Hercules (Pure Magic): released as ''Herkules'' & ''Legend of Herkules'' (PS, PS2)
* Mulan (Django Studios): released as ''Legend of Mulan'' & ''Mighty Mulan ''(PS, PS2)
* Board Game Gallery (announced 2004)<ref>[https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/news140704psp PSP Game announcement 2004]</ref>
* [http://web.archive.org/web/20081112224705/http://www.phoenixgamesgroup.com/uk/available.html List of every Game by 12th November 2008]
* [http://web.archive.org/web/20081112150551/http://www.phoenixgamesgroup.com/uk/release.html List of planned games by 12th November 2008]

[[Category:Video game development companies]]","'''''Phoenix Games''''' is a partly-defunct Dutch video game publisher founded by Willie Horden, Paul Share and Steve Share, that released a large amount of low-effort titles for the Sony [[PlayStation]], [[PlayStation 2]], [[Nintendo DS]], [[Microsoft Windows]] and the Nintendo [[Wii]]. They had contracts with over 50 developer Studios around the globe.

They published games based on [[Dingo Pictures]] films on the aforementioned consoles (barring Windows). Their last known published game was Lion and the King 3 on Nintendo DS, released on February 12th, 2010.

The German Video Game Archive claims that they published 99 games on the PlayStation 2 alone.<ref name=\":0\">[http://www.gamereset.de/va/coverstrophen.html Coverstropfen] on German Videogamearchive</ref>

Phoenix Games was devised between three companies, Phoenix Games B.V., Phoenix Games Ltd. and Phoenix Games Asia. The group was an exhibitor at E3 in 2005.<ref>[https://www.giantbomb.com/e3-2005/3015-3437/ E3 2005] Giantbomb.com</ref> Also they went to ECTS2003.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Phoenix Games: PS2, PSX, PC and XBOX

column1: Founded in May 2002 by Willie Horden<ref>[https://www.linkedin.com/in/williehorden/?originalSubdomain=nl Willie Horden] LinkedIn Profile - Only Visible for Logged in Users</ref> and Paul and Steve Share. They had a UK subsidiary based in Leicester. They were exhibitors of E3 2004<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Getting an education in video games at E3
column7: access-date=2020-04-12}}</ref> 2005<ref>[https://www.giantbomb.com/e3-2006/3015-3439/ List of Exhibitos at E3 2006] on Giantbomb.com</ref> and 2006<ref>{{Cite web
column12: access-date=2020-04-12}}</ref> and were located in De Pinckart 46g, 5674 CC Nuenen in the Netherlands.

column1: Phoenix Games B.V. declared bankruptcy on August 3rd, 2010. On March 27th, 2012 the bankruptcy was suspended due to a lack of income.<ref>[https://drimble.nl/faillissementen/noord-brabant/eindhoven/17160750/phoenix-games-holland-bv.html Phoenix Games] on drimble.nl (Dutch)</ref>

column1: In film, she is best known for her roles in ''[[Ronin_(film)
column3: Solaris]]'' (2002). On television, she has portrayed Karen van der Beek, the long-time partner of [[Hank Moody]], in the [[Showtime (TV network)
column5: Californication]]'' (2007–2014), [[First Lady]] Alex Kirkman in the [[American Broadcasting Company
column9: title='Designated Survivor' Casts Kal Penn, Maggie Q, Natascha McElhone, Italia Ricci
column13: work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]}}</ref> (2016–2017), and Laz Ingram in [[Beau Willimon]]'s [[Hulu]] science-fiction series ''[[The First (TV series)

column1: She was born Natasha Abigail Taylor in Walton-on-Thames, [[Surrey]] in 1969<ref>{{cite web
column15: access-date = 2018-08-22 }}</ref> to Noreen McElhone and Michael Taylor, both journalists.<ref>{{cite web
column18: newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> She took her mother's maiden name as her stage name.<ref>{{cite web
column23: scriptwriter]] brother, Damon, who lives in [[Los Angeles]]; and two half-brothers: Alexander, who lives in [[Zürich]], and Nicholas, who lives in [[Stockholm]]. Her parents separated when she was two. Her [[Irish people
column24: Irish]] mother moved the family to [[Brighton]] and later married journalist and columnist [[Roy Greenslade]].<ref>{{cite news
column28: title=Comedy role for X-Files star Duchovny

column1: McElhone, who took lessons in [[Irish dancing]] from ages 6–12, was educated at St. Mark's CofE Primary School, Brighton, [[St Mary's Hall, Brighton
column2: St. Mary's Hall]] School for Girls, an independent [[boarding school]] in [[Brighton]], [[Sussex]], Fortismere School, London, Camden School for Girls, London and William Ellis, London. She graduated from the [[London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art]] in 1993.<ref name=\"Natascha\">{{cite web

column1: McElhone began her career in the theatre, including starring roles in ''[[Richard III (play)
column2: Richard III]]'' and ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'' at the [[Open Air Theatre, Regent's Park]], London, and in ''[[The Count of Monte Cristo]]'' and ''[[The Cherry Orchard]]'' at the [[Haymarket Theatre (Leicester)
column3: Haymarket Theatre]], [[Leicester]]. She made her television debut in the [[BBC]]'s ''[[Bergerac (TV series)
column4: Bergerac]]'' in 1991 (credited on screen as Natascha Taylor), and was seen in an episode of ''[[Absolutely Fabulous]]'' in 1992.<ref>{{cite web
McElhone at the [[Southbank Centre]], London in March 2014]]

column1: McElhone was seen in two episodes of the [[Dennis Potter]] TV miniseries ''[[Karaoke (play)
column2: Karaoke]]''. Her first major box-office role came in 1996 with ''[[Surviving Picasso]]'', with co-star [[Anthony Hopkins]]. One of her most successful films to date has been 1998's ''[[The Truman Show]]'' with [[Jim Carrey]]. She had leading roles opposite [[Brad Pitt]] in ''[[The Devil's Own]]'', [[Robert De Niro]] in ''[[Ronin (film)

column1: In 2005, she co-starred in the [[NBC]] miniseries ''[[Revelations (2005 TV series)
column2: Revelations]]'' with [[Bill Pullman]]. She starred in a 2006 West End production of ''Honour'' at the [[Wyndham's Theatre]] alongside [[Diana Rigg]] and [[Martin Jarvis (actor)
column3: Martin Jarvis]]. She then accepted a leading role in the Showtime cable television series ''[[Californication (TV series)
column4: Californication]]'' as Karen, alongside [[David Duchovny]].<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Interview: Natascha McElhone on becoming a writer
column7: website=www.scotsman.com}}</ref> In 2009 McElhone became a spokeswoman for [[Neutrogena]].<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Neutrogena Casts Natascha McElhone; Valentino Does ‘Fearless’ Eyes
column13: accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref> In 2010, she was the voice of Marie in the video game ''[[Castlevania: Lords of Shadow]]'' from [[Konami]].<ref name=\"cv\">{{cite news
column14: title=Konami Announces Castlevania: Lords Of Shadow is Now Available

column1: McElhone co-starred in a 2013 [[Romeo and Juliet (2013 film)
column2: adaptation]] of ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' as Juliet's mother, [[Lady Capulet]], alongside [[Hailee Steinfeld]] and [[Damian Lewis]].<ref>{{cite news
column5: title='Homeland' Star Damian Lewis Cast in 'Romeo and Juliet' (Exclusive)
column9: date=1 February 2012}}</ref> In 2014, she played the role of Alex Forrest in ''[[Fatal Attraction (play)
column10: Fatal Attraction]]'', at the [[Theatre Royal Haymarket]]. In 2015, McElhone starred as [[Sarah Churchill, Duchess of Marlborough
column11: Sarah Churchill]] in the [[Royal Shakespeare Company
column12: Royal Shakespeare Company's]] production of [[Helen Edmundson

column1: In February 2016, she was cast alongside [[Kiefer Sutherland]] in [[American Broadcasting Company
column3: Designated Survivor]]'', which premiered in September 2016.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=‘Designated Survivor’ Casts Kal Penn, Maggie Q, Natascha McElhone, Italia Ricci
column10: date=5 February 2016}}</ref>. She left the show in Season 2 to take a role in the Hulu series ''[[The First (TV series)

column4: date=July 2019}} The couple lived in [[Fulham]], West London, with their sons Theodore (born 2000) and Otis (born May 2003); their third son, Rex, was born in October 2008, five months after Kelly's death.<ref>{{cite web

column1: On 20 May 2008, 43-year-old Kelly was found slumped in the doorway of his family's home by a fellow doctor, who had him rushed to [[Chelsea and Westminster Hospital]] (where he worked). However, he could not be revived. He died one day after his 10th wedding anniversary. A [[autopsy
column2: postmortem exam]] revealed the cause of death to have been [[dilated cardiomyopathy]].<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Natascha McElhone's plastic surgeon husband dies at couple's home

column1: After her husband's sudden death, McElhone continued to write letters to him, sometimes documenting the daily trivia of life but also dealing with how she and their young children were [[coping (psychology)
column2: coping]] with their loss. These letters and diary entries formed the basis of her book ''After You: Letters of Love, and Loss, to a Husband and Father''. The book was published in July 2010 (the book is titled ''After You'' in the UK [[Amazon Kindle
column6: title=After You: Letters of Love, and Loss, to a Husband and Father by Natascha McElhone
column13: title = After you: letters of love, and loss, to a husband and father

column10: Fatal Attraction]]'', at the [[Theatre Royal Haymarket]]. In 2015, McElhone starred as [[Sarah Churchill, Duchess of Marlborough

column12: Royal Shakespeare Company's]] production of [[Helen Edmundson

column1: In February 2016, she was cast alongside [[Kiefer Sutherland]] in [[American Broadcasting Company
column3: Designated Survivor]]'', which premiered in September 2016.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=‘Designated Survivor’ Casts Kal Penn, Maggie Q, Natascha McElhone, Italia Ricci
column10: date=5 February 2016}}</ref>. She left the show in Season 2 to take a role in the Hulu series ''[[The First (TV series)

column4: date=July 2019}} The couple lived in [[Fulham]], West London, with their sons Theodore (born 2000) and Otis (born May 2003); their third son, Rex, was born in October 2008, five months after Kelly's death.<ref>{{cite web

column1: On 20 May 2008, 43-year-old Kelly was found slumped in the doorway of his family's home by a fellow doctor, who had him rushed to [[Chelsea and Westminster Hospital]] (where he worked). However, he could not be revived. He died one day after his 10th wedding anniversary. A [[autopsy
column2: postmortem exam]] revealed the cause of death to have been [[dilated cardiomyopathy]].<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Natascha McElhone's plastic surgeon husband dies at couple's home

column1: After her husband's sudden death, McElhone continued to write letters to him, sometimes documenting the daily trivia of life but also dealing with how she and their young children were [[coping (psychology)
column2: coping]] with their loss. These letters and diary entries formed the basis of her book ''After You: Letters of Love, and Loss, to a Husband and Father''. The book was published in July 2010 (the book is titled ''After You'' in the UK [[Amazon Kindle

column2: caption     = An early photograph of the medieval Burton Bridge looking from the town (Parliamentarian) side of the river

column1: The '''Battle of Burton Bridge''' was fought between Royalist and Parliamentarian forces at [[Burton upon Trent]] on 4 July 1643 during the [[First English Civil War]].  By the time of the battle the town, which had at various times been held by both sides, was garrisoned by a Parliamentarian unit under the command of Captain Thomas Sanders and the town's military governor, Colonel Richard Houghton.  The key river crossing at Burton was desired by Queen [[Henrietta Maria of France
column2: Henrietta Maria]], who was proceeding southwards from Yorkshire with a convoy of supplies destined for King [[Charles I of England
column3: Charles I]] at Oxford.  The Royalists, led by Colonel [[Thomas Tyldesley]], launched a cavalry charge across the bridge which succeeded in defeating the Parliamentarians and capturing most of their officers, including Sanders and Houghton.  The Queen's convoy proceeded on its way south to Oxford with Tyldesley receiving a knighthood and a promotion in recognition of his victory.  Burton changed hands several more times during the course of the war, before finally coming into Parliament's control in 1646.

column1: The county of Staffordshire, several days travel from the main seat of power in London, had a long-standing disinclination to paying taxes and levies imposed by the King.  [[James I]]'s [[Privy Council of England
column2: Privy Council]] was forced to write to the county's [[Justices of the Peace]] for their failure to raise a single penny to support the King's [[Palatinate campaign
column3: campaign to reclaim the Palatinate]] in [[Holy Roman Empire
column4: Germany]] for his son-in-law [[Frederick V, Elector Palatine
column8: p=3}}.</ref>  The county was also slow to pay [[Charles I of England
column9: Charles I]]'s [[ship money]] which began to be levied (in defiance of the Parliament) on the inland counties in 1634 and saw much resistance.<ref name=\"p3\"/>  Open dissent against the King's decrees occurred in 1640 in objection to the levying of 300 men from the county for the King's [[Bishops' Wars
column13: p=5}}.</ref>  Riots took place in [[Uttoxeter]] with an armed guard having to be formed to prevent the levy from deserting.<ref name=\"p5\"/>

column1: Upon the outbreak of the Civil War in 1642 the town of Burton was largely sympathetic to the Parliamentarian cause.<ref name=county>Tringham, General History.</ref>   This was probably, in part, due to the large [[Puritan]] following in the town and Staffordshire's general disapproval of the [[High Church]] practices of the then Archbishop of Canterbury [[William Laud]] (who was later executed for his opposition of Puritanism).<ref name=county/><ref name=\"p4\">{{Harvnb
Burton's river crossing, a 36-arched medieval structure known as \"Burton Bridge\", was desirable to both sides, being described as \"the only passage over the [[River Trent
column3: Dove]] to the North\", and was positioned between the Royalist towns of Lichfield, Tutbury, and Ashby-de-la-Zouch and Parliamentarian Stafford and Derby.<ref name=county/><ref name=\"p19\">{{Harvnb
column6: p=19}}.</ref>  Despite this strategic location the town was unfortified and possessed few natural defences.<ref name=county/>  Burton would change hands at least a dozen times during the course of the war, first coming to the attention of the Royalists when the [[Philip Stanhope, 1st Earl of Chesterfield
column7: Earl of Chesterfield]] used it as a rendezvous for his forces in late 1642.<ref name=county/>  Chesterfield withdrew his forces to Lichfield for the winter, garrisoning the [[Lichfield Cathedral
column8: cathedral]] which would be the scene of much fighting during the war.<ref name=\"p15\">{{Harvnb
column11: p=15}}.</ref>  There were rumours prior to the war that the town held secret supplies of gunpowder for a catholic rebellion, these were investigated by [[William Paget, 5th Baron Paget
column12: Lord Paget]] (who began the war as a parliamentarian, switched allegiance to the King in 1642 before returning to the side of Parliament in 1644) and found to be false, though the explosion of a store of gunpowder did occur in 1643 causing the roof of [[St Modwen's, Burton upon Trent
column13: St Modwen's Church]] to be destroyed.<ref name=county/><ref>Tringham, Established Church.</ref>

column1: East Staffordshire's strategic importance was heightened by its position at the boundary of Royalist and Parliamentarian garrisons in the region.<ref name=\"p16\">{{Harvnb
column4: p=16}}.</ref>  Burton had come to [[roundhead]] attention in early 1643 after the establishment of a garrison at nearby Derby by the county committee leader, [[Sir John Gell, 1st Baronet
column5: Sir John Gell]].<ref name=county/>  In February Gell placed a garrison across the county border at Burton, consisting of an infantry company under Dutch Major Johannes Molanus, but withdrew it less than a month later to assist in an [[Newark-on-Trent#The Civil War

column1: Parliament's forces in Staffordshire and Warwickshire were initially under the command of [[Robert Greville, 2nd Baron Brooke
column2: Lord Brooke]] but after his death during the successful siege of Lichfield Cathedral in March 1643 Gell was appointed as his replacement.<ref name=\"p16\"/>  Shortly thereafter, Gell whose forces amounted to around 1,000 infantry, a few horse and 300 partially armed [[Staffordshire Moorlands
column3: Staffordshire moorlanders]] met with [[Sir William Brereton, 1st Baronet
column4: Sir William Brereton]], Commander-in-Chief of Cheshire, to organise an attack upon Stafford.<ref name=\"p16\"/>  This became known to the Royalists and the [[Spencer Compton, 2nd Earl of Northampton
column5: Earl of Northampton]] was sent with two fast-moving cavalry regiments to thwart Gell and Brereton's plan.<ref name=\"p17\">{{Harvnb
column8: p=17}}.</ref>  Northampton met with troops led by [[Henry Hastings, 1st Baron Loughborough
column9: Henry Hastings]] (later Lord Loughborough) and garrisoned Tamworth before engaging Gell at the inconclusive [[Battle of Hopton Heath]], during which Northampton was killed.<ref name=\"p17\"/>

column1: During this time [[Henrietta Maria of France
column2: Queen Henrietta Maria]] landed at [[Bridlington]], Yorkshire with a supply of weapons purchased abroad that she intended to bring to the King, who was then in [[Oxford]].<ref name=\"p19\"/>  In advance of this the King sent his nephew, [[Prince Rupert of the Rhine]], from Oxford with 1,200 horse, 700 foot and 6 cannon to clear South Staffordshire.<ref name=\"p19\"/>  Prince Rupert's troops evicted garrisons from [[Rushall, West Midlands
column3: Rushall]] and [[Birmingham]] and successfully [[Lichfield Cathedral#Devastation of the English Civil War
column4: recaptured Lichfield]].<ref name=\"p19\"/>  Rupert placed Royalist garrison in key towns including Burton to secure the route of Henrietta's convoy.<ref name=\"p19\"/>  The garrison at Burton was soon driven out once more by Gell, acting in co-operation with [[Thomas Grey, Lord Grey of Groby
column5: Lord Grey]], commander-in-chief of the East Midlands Association.<ref name=county/>  He placed his own garrison there of 200 infantry, 60 dragoons and a cannon from Derbyshire before proceeding with the remainder of his force to [[Tutbury Castle]] which he unsuccessfully attacked.<ref name=\"county\"/><ref name=\"Lewisp19\">{{Harvnb

column1: Gell's garrison at Burton was commanded by Captain Thomas Sanders, who had previously commanded one of the largest companies in Gell's force.<ref name=\"p19\"/>  Sanders held more radical political views than Gell and was seen as a potential rival.<ref name=\"p19\"/>  Sanders may have been concerned that his deployment to such a precarious position was a plot by Gell to be rid of him.<ref name=county/>  Whatever the case Sanders decided to remove himself from Gell's command and place him and his men under the direction of Colonel Richard Houghton, of the Staffordshire county committee and military governor of Burton.<ref name=county/><ref name=\"p20\"/>
In July 1643 the Queen's convoy and its guard advanced from Newark to [[Ashby-de-la-Zouch]] and then to Burton.<ref name=\"p20\">{{Harvnb
column4: p=20}}.</ref>  Gell summoned the Staffordshire and Nottinghamshire associations forces to defend the town but they refused to [[Muster (military)
column5: muster]] for him.<ref name=\"p20\"/>  On 4 July 1643 the Roylist cavalry, led by Colonel [[Thomas Tyldesley]], charged across Burton Bridge and engaged Sanders' men.<ref name=county/> The engagement was described as \"bloody\" and \"desperate\" and, though damage was caused to the town's St Modwen's church, the battle seems to have been decided by the action at the bridge.<ref name=\"p20l\"/><ref name=lanc>Remember Sir Thomas.</ref>  The forces of parliament were decisively beaten and, according to Gell, the town was \"most miserably plundered and destroyed\".<ref name=\"p20\"/>  Henrietta Maria herself recorded that so much loot was taken that her men \"could not well march with their bundles\".<ref name=county/>

column1: The Royalists claimed that they had twice requested the surrender of the town before they attacked and that the Queen forbade any violence against the townsfolk.<ref name=\"p20l\">{{Harvnb
column4: p=20}}.</ref>  Conversely the parliamentarians claimed that 30 of their men were forced into the church and offered to surrender but were refused and were killed by cavaliers in the night.<ref name=\"p20l\"/>  The Royalists were also alleged to have looted the town and raped women before drowning at least 20 civilians in the river.<ref name=\"p20l\"/>  The Royalists took most of the Roundhead officers prisoner including Captain Sanders and Colonel Houghton (and his wife).<ref name=\"p20\"/><ref name=\"p20l\"/>  Sanders was later exchanged and was promoted to Major by the [[Robert Devereux, 3rd Earl of Essex
column5: Earl of Essex]] and commissioned by Gell to act as Colonel and to raise a regiment of horse.<ref name=\"p20\"/>  Tyldesley was knighted and promoted to brigadier-general for bravery shown in the action.<ref name=\"ODNB\">Blackwood.</ref>

column1: Having lost Burton, Gell feared an attack upon Derby and withdrew troops from [[Nottingham]] and [[Leicester]] to defend it.<ref name=\"p21\">{{Harvnb
column4: p=21}}.</ref> He was also able to secure supplies of 20 barrels of powder, 300 muskets, 60 carbines and 60 cases of pistols and an additional troop of horses, allowing him to arm his regiment fully for the first time.<ref name=\"p21\"/>  However Derby was not attacked by the Queen's forces who bypassed it and moved through Walsall, proceeding according to the King's instructions to avoid delays.<ref name=\"p21\"/>

column1: The new Royalist garrison in Burton fortified the bridge and maintained control of the town until driven out by Gell in January 1644.<ref name=county/>  During this attack Gell took the commanding officer (a Major), six captains, eight other officers and 500 men prisoner.<ref name=\"p31\">{{Harvnb
column4: p=31}}.</ref>  Burton Bridge was again a focal point of the assault with five Royalists losing their lives there, with Gell claiming that he lost no men in the attack.<ref name=\"p31\"/>  Gell withdrew with his prisoners to Derby, allowing Lord Loughborough to retake the town and bridge which he intended to hold as a means of communication between his \"flying army\" at Ashby and the Royalist garrisons in Tutbury and Derbyshire.<ref name=\"p31\"/>

column1: A Parliamentarian raid again attacked and plundered the town in April 1644, afterwards ceding control to the Royalists once more, before Sanders' newly raised regiment of 400 horse retook it  narrowly failing to capture Loughborough himself.<ref name=county/><ref name=\"p31\"/>  Parliament troops from Derbyshire and Staffordshire were established as a garrison in November 1644 but were driven out by Royalists by February 1645.<ref name=county/>  King Charles I briefly made Burton his headquarters in May of that year before the town was retaken for the final time by Parliament in early 1646, becoming a centre of supply of coin and beer to the forces besieging Tutbury and Lichfield.<ref name=county/>  After the war and the [[Restoration (England)
column2: Restoration of Charles II]] in 1660 Burton remained a place of [[English Dissenters
column4: nonconformism]] with large [[Presbyterian]] and [[Baptist]] congregations, raising doubts within the [[Church of England]] over the town's loyalty.<ref name=county/>

column1: The medieval bridge over which the battle was fought was replaced in the Victorian era.<ref name=county/>  A plaque commemorating the battle was erected on the bridge on 2 July 1993 by Sir Thomas Tyldesley's Regiment of the [[English Civil War Society]].{{efn
column2: The plaque on the modern bridge commemorating the battle reads: \"near this spot on 2nd July 1643, during the English Civil War, Colonel Thomas Tyldesley led a desperate cavalry charge over the famous 36-arched Trent Bridge to storm the town of Burton, the event being personally witnessed by Queen Henrietta Maria. For this exploit of signal valour, Thomas Tyldesley was subsequently knighted by King Charles I.  This plaque was erected on 2nd July 1993 by Sir Thomas Tyldesley's Regiment of the English Civil War Society and Burton upon Trent Civic Society.\"}}

column1: Another monument erected at the site of Tyldesley's death at the [[Battle of Wigan Lane]] by one of his [[Cornet (military rank)
column2: cornets]], Alexander Rigby, in 1679 notes his \"desperate storming of Burton-Upon-Trent over a bridge of 36 arches [for which Tyldesley] received the honour of Knighthood\".<ref name=lanc/>  In honour of the battle the [[Burton Bridge Brewery]] markets an ale known as \"Battle Brew\".<ref>Battle Brew.</ref>  A local legend states that Oliver Cromwell was present in the area during the battle and tied his horse to a nail at [[Tatenhill]]'s St Michael's and All Angels Church, just {{convert
column5: km}} from the bridge.<ref>Moody.</ref> The medieval Burton bridge was the site of [[Battle of Burton Bridge (1322)
column6: an earlier battle]] in 1322 where [[Edward II of England
column7: Edward II]] defeated the rebellious [[Thomas, 2nd Earl of Lancaster

column4: title=All is well at church's holey site

title=A History of the County of Stafford: Volume 9 - Burton-upon-Trent — General History

column1: A Parliamentarian raid again attacked and plundered the town in April 1644, afterwards ceding control to the Royalists once more, before Sanders' newly raised regiment of 400 horse retook it  narrowly failing to capture Loughborough himself.<ref name=county/><ref name=\"p31\"/>  Parliament troops from Derbyshire and Staffordshire were established as a garrison in November 1644 but were driven out by Royalists by February 1645.<ref name=county/>  King Charles I briefly made Burton his headquarters in May of that year before the town was retaken for the final time by Parliament in early 1646, becoming a centre of supply of coin and beer to the forces besieging Tutbury and Lichfield.<ref name=county/>  After the war and the [[Restoration (England)
column2: Restoration of Charles II]] in 1660 Burton remained a place of [[English Dissenters
column4: nonconformism]] with large [[Presbyterian]] and [[Baptist]] congregations, raising doubts within the [[Church of England]] over the town's loyalty.<ref name=county/>

column1: The medieval bridge over which the battle was fought was replaced in the Victorian era.<ref name=county/>  A plaque commemorating the battle was erected on the bridge on 2 July 1993 by Sir Thomas Tyldesley's Regiment of the [[English Civil War Society]] (the umbrella group for English Civil War re-enactors).<ref name=plaque/> Another monument erected at the site of Tyldesley's death at the [[Battle of Wigan Lane]] by one of his [[Cornet (military rank)
column2: cornets]], Alexander Rigby, in 1679 notes his \"desperate storming of Burton-Upon-Trent over a bridge of 36 arches [for which Tyldesley] received the honour of Knighthood\".<ref name=lanc/>  In honour of the battle the [[Burton Bridge Brewery]] markets an ale known as \"Battle Brew\".<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=26 February 2012}}</ref>  A local legend states that Oliver Cromwell was present in the area during the battle and tied his horse to a nail at [[Tatenhill]]'s St Michael's and All Angels Church, just {{convert
column12: title=All is well at church's holey site
column16: date=19 February 2009}}</ref>  The medieval Burton bridge was the site of [[Battle of Burton Bridge (1322)
column17: an earlier battle]] in 1322 where [[Edward II of England
column18: Edward II]] defeated the rebellious [[Thomas, 2nd Earl of Lancaster
